sub_topic: Calculation of Gibbs free energy change for a chemical reaction
message_1:
Calculate the Gibbs free energy change for the following reaction at 298 K:
2CH4(g) + 3O2(g) → 2CO2(g) + 2H2O(g)
Given the standard Gibbs free energy of formation at 298 K for CH4(g), O2(g), CO2(g) and H2O(g) are -50.8 kJ/mol, 0 kJ/mol, -394.4 kJ/mol, and -241.8 kJ/mol respectively.
message_2:
To calculate the Gibbs free energy change (ΔG) for the reaction, we can use the following equation:

ΔG = Σ ΔG(products) - Σ ΔG(reactants)

where ΔG(products) is the sum of the standard Gibbs free energy of formation for the products and ΔG(reactants) is the sum of the standard Gibbs free energy of formation for the reactants.

For the given reaction:

2CH4(g) + 3O2(g) → 2CO2(g) + 2H2O(g)

ΔG(products) = [2 × (-394.4 kJ/mol)] + [2 × (-241.8 kJ/mol)] = -788.8 kJ/mol - 483.6 kJ/mol = -1272.4 kJ/mol

ΔG(reactants) = [2 × (-50.8 kJ/mol)] + [3 × (0 kJ/mol)] = -101.6 kJ/mol

Now, we can calculate ΔG for the reaction:

ΔG = Σ ΔG(products) - Σ ΔG(reactants) = -1272.4 kJ/mol - (-101.6 kJ/mol) = -1170.8 kJ/mol

So, the Gibbs free energy change for the reaction at 298 K is -1170.8 kJ/mol.
